title: Moving out
content:
Time has not been kind to us and so every Keener that is still a child in his heart once move out.
Because my parents finally decided to kick me out me too have to find a new place.

So I wonder, how many of you live on your own?

I'm going to take a look...
no, people of this house are going to take a look at me.
[img]http://www.sls.nl/uploads/import/thumbs/21%20middelstegracht%2020.jpg[/img]
Updates will (probably) follow.-----------------

title: Re: Moving out
content:
I have the best of both worlds, living in the back shed, which has been converted into a flat. It still needs some work to be completely livable, but at least I have my room now. For 8 months last year it was just a frame covered with tarps--as of November or so, I have plaster. And a door. With a lock.

I must upload some photos of its gradual development sometime.

Mum has plans to move to Cairns in the near future. Hopefully that works out, because then I get to rent the entire house on the cheap and can turn this shed into a computer lab.[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-drool.gif[/img]

title: Re: Moving out
content:
Funny how lots of people think that because you turn 18 (or some other arbitrarily significant number) you have to suddenly go and live somewhere away from the rest of your family. That's actually just a small cultural phenomenon rather than a law or large-scale social expectation, and it's not as common as American Sitcoms would have you believe.

But if you want to go and study in some place where your family doesn't live, then you gotta do whatcha gotta do! Good luck to you sir (or, rather, better luck than I had when I did it, hehe)!! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img] ----------
www.StrifeStrips.com! Woot! We're back, baby!

title: Re: Moving out
content:
Due when you gotta be out, Djaser? And what are you going to study? History?

Philosophy is interesting, no doubt, but I'm just not completely sure whether I'm actually wanting to study it (I do like to read that stuff, though, even if not studying at university).. You see, first I was going to study Computer Science (or planned to, a few years ago), then planned art history (which too bad can be studied only as something part time study instead of full time in the local university -- there's an university where you can study it full time, but unfortunately it's not in my town). Yeah.. No idea what's going to happen. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-garg.gif[/img]

And yeah, there are plenty of people living home after they've turned 18 (I turn 19 in a month).3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: Moving out
content:
History? Almost right I'm going to study TCMA which means that I'm going to learn how to read little clay tablets like this one. (this is no joke)
[img]http://www.betnahrain.org/Glossary/Clay_tablet/comet_final.gif[/img]
And of course that means that I'll have to do a lot history too.
I'll start somewhere this fall.

I wouldn't let practical reason limit your choice. You won't get much more chances to do a study you like. Good luck anyway.

title: Re: Moving out
content:
You shouldn't be worried about moving out, I moved out a couple of months before I turned 21 and in the year or so since then I haven't looked back - living on your own is fantastic, there's nobody to remind you to do chores, no one cares if you have music going all the time (I used to have to put it on headphones when my parents went to bed) and you can leave old computers all over the floor and nobody complains about the mess [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img] Not to mention being able to buy only food you really like and to sleep in on weekends without being woken up early...

Can you tell I was only too keen to move out??? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

[hr]KeenRush I don't look forward moving out just because everything gets to much complicated then.
[hr]
That's what I used to think, but it's actually nowhere near as bad as you expect. You don't really need to know anything about living on your own, beyond looking after yourself (remembering to buy food, doing the washing, etc) - you get reminders in the mail for everything else (like paying bills) and stuff like that always has instructions in case you've never done it before, so it's always easy.
